questions.text: An image of a perianal disease is shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Fistula in Ano


The correct diagnosis is Fistula in Ano. A fistula in ano is an abnormal connection between the interior of the anal canal and the perianal skin. It often presents as a recurrent swelling or abscess near the anal verge, which may drain spontaneously. The key clues include the location of the swelling near the anal verge and the history of recurrent discharge, making it characteristic of a fistula in ano.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pilonidal Sinus: A pilonidal sinus is typically found in the upper part of the natal cleft, far from the anal verge, and is associated with hair follicles in the gluteal region. It commonly affects young men with a hairy back and is located above the coccyx, not near the anus. The key distinction is the location; pilonidal sinuses are not found at the anal verge but higher up in the gluteal cleft.

 

 

Option C. Fissure in Ano: A fissure in ano is a linear tear in the lining of the anus, usually caused by trauma or hard stools. It presents with pain during defecation and bright red bleeding but not with a swelling or external opening as seen in fistula in ano. There may be a hypertrophic skin tag covering it (Sentinel pile). Fissures do not have a history of recurrent discharge or a swelling appearance near the anal verge.

 

 

Option D. Hemorrhoids: Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus and typically present with painless bleeding, itching, and swelling inside the anal canal or at the anal verge. They do not present with the external openings, recurrent abscesses, or discharging sinuses characteristic of fistula in ano.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Fistula in Ano should be considered when there is a history of recurrent swelling, abscess formation, or discharge near the anal verge. It is distinguished from pilonidal sinus by its lower location near the anal canal, as opposed to pilonidal sinuses that occur higher up in the natal cleft.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows widened mediastinum. BP is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute aortic dissection

 

  • Patient with sudden-onset severe chest pain, with a difference in blood pressure between the two limbs, and a widened mediastinum on x-ray suggests a diagnosis of acute aortic dissection.
  • AORTIC DISSECTION is tear in intima of aorta

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): ACS includes conditions such as myocardial infarction and unstable angina. These conditions typically present with chest pain but do not usually cause blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option B. Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism presents with sudden onset dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and signs of right heart strain. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs or a widened mediastinum.

 

Option D. Esophageal Rupture: Esophageal rupture can present with severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, and signs of sepsis. It does not typically present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs. It may cause mediastinal widening but would more likely present with other signs such as subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The classic presentation of acute aortic dissection includes sudden severe chest pain radiating to the neck and back, a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray.
  • Immediate imaging with a CT thoracic angiogram and lowering blood pressure are crucial steps in management.

questions.text: A female is cooking in the kitchen. Suddenly the cooker blasts, leading to dermo-epidermal burns of the face with singeing of eyebrows, bilateral upper limbs, and front of chest. What is the area of the burn? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 27-30%

 

Using Wallace's Rule of Nines for calculating Total Body Surface Area (TBSA) in adults: 

 

Bilateral upper limbs account for 9% each (total 18%), the anterior chest represents 9% (anterior trunk is 18% total, with chest being half of this), and partial face involvement from the cooker blast adds approximately 4-4.5% (since the entire head and neck together equal 9%). 

 

Singeing of eyebrows indicates facial burns from the explosion. 

 

The calculation yields: 18% (bilateral upper limbs) + 9% (anterior chest) + 4% (partial face) = 31% maximum. 

 

Since facial involvement is partial, the realistic range is 27-30% TBSA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In adults using Wallace's Rule of Nines: head and neck = 9%, each upper limb = 9%, anterior trunk = 18%, with face alone representing approximately 4-4.5% of TBSA.

questions.text: Identify the correct labelling of the ulcer in the given image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Edge

 

Parts of an ulcer are clearly defined:

 

 

Edge: Junction between floor and skin 

 

Floor: Visible surface of ulcer that can be seen

 

Base: Tissue on which floor rests (not visible but can be palpated)

 

Margin: Where edge merges with surrounding healthy skin

 

Key characteristics:

 

Edge provides important diagnostic clues:

 

  • Punched out in trophic ulcer
  • Undermined in tuberculous ulcer
  • Everted in malignant ulcer
  • Sloping in healing ulcer

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edge of an ulcer is the junction between floor and surrounding skin, and its characteristics provide important diagnostic clues.

questions.text: A patient following head injury with altered consciousness, vomiting, and GCS of 10/15 undergoes CT scan as shown. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompression

 

The patient presents with signs of an acute epidural hematoma (EDH), as evidenced by the biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion on the CT scan, along with a deteriorating Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10/15. An epidural hematoma is a neurosurgical emergency, especially when accompanied by neuro deterioration, as in this case. The immediate next step is decompression, which involves relieving the pressure on the brain by surgically removing the hematoma. This procedure can be done through a burr hole or craniotomy and is crucial to prevent further brain injury or death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Mannitol: Although IV mannitol is used to reduce intracranial pressure, it is not the definitive treatment for an acute EDH with neuro deterioration. Mannitol may be used temporarily to manage intracranial pressure, but it does not address the underlying cause of the pressure, which is the hematoma.

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This approach is inappropriate in this scenario due to the immediate threat posed by the hematoma. Delaying treatment could lead to irreversible brain damage or death.

 

Option D. Anticoagulation: Administering anticoagulation would exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient’s condition. It is contraindicated in the setting of an active intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidural hematoma with neuro deterioration is a neurosurgical emergency that requires immediate decompression to prevent further brain injury and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman who had an abdominal hysterectomy two years ago and is now experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting bile, high-pitched bowel sounds during examination. The presence of air within the biliary tree is seen on diagnostic tests. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of intestinal obstruction. Though adhesions could be the reason, the presence of air in biliary tree makes a diagnosis of gallstone ileus more likely.

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis, occurring due to the impaction of gallstones in the gastrointestinal tract. This occurs due to chronic gall bladder inflammation and formation of cholecysto-duodenal fistula (GB to duodenum). Through the communication, a gall stone may pass into the duodenum and then into small bowel.
  • Small gallstones may pass through the intestines spontaneously, but larger stones (2-5 cm) are more likely to cause obstruction, usually at the terminal ileum or ileocecal valve.
  • Symptoms may include acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of gastrointestinal obstruction, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice.
  • Diagnosis is typically made with a plain abdominal radiograph, which may show signs of obstruction, Pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree), and a gallstone in the intestines (RIGLER’S TRIAD).
  • Treatment involves surgical intervention, with a longitudinal incision made on the antimesenteric border to remove the gallstone.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Adhesive intestinal obstruction: This results from the formation of adhesions (bands of scar tissue) that can develop after surgery, which then bind the intestines together. These adhesions can pull the intestines out of place or create a kink or twist. The patient's history of an abdominal hysterectomy is suggestive of this, as post-surgical adhesions are a common cause of intestinal obstruction. However, the presence of air in the biliary tree does not fit with this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Ischemic enterocolitis: Refers to inflammation of the intestine due to reduced blood supply, often caused by blockage or constriction of the blood vessels that serve the intestines. Symptoms typically include sudden abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. While ischemic processes can cause pain and altered bowel sounds, the presence of pneumobilia on imaging is not consistent with ischemic enterocolitis.

 

Option D. Diverticulitis: Diverticulitis is the inflammation of one or more diverticula, which are small pouches that can form in the walls of the colon. Symptoms include lower left-sided abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits. While diverticulitis can lead to complications like abscesses, fistulas, or bowel obstructions, the specific presentation of vomiting bile and air within the biliary tree on imaging is not consistent with a primary diagnosis of diverticulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis characterized by the presence of air within the biliary tree, obstructive symptoms, and the formation of a cholecysto-duodenal fistula.
  • It typically presents with signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and is diagnosed through imaging, revealing pneumobilia and a gallstone in the intestines.

questions.text: Identify the parameter seen in all types of shock: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreased Tissue Perfusion

 

Decreased tissue perfusion is a constant feature in all types of shock. Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion that is inadequate for normal cellular respiration. Regardless of the type, the hallmark of shock is reduced blood flow to the tissues, resulting in insufficient oxygen delivery and nutrient supply to meet the cellular needs, leading to cellular and tissue hypoxia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased Temperature: Increased temperature or fever is not seen in all types of shock. It is commonly seen in septic shock due to the systemic inflammatory response to infection.

 

Option B. Increased Pulse Pressure: Increased pulse pressure is not a consistent finding in all types of shock. In fact, pulse pressure often narrows in states like hypovolemic and cardiogenic shock.

 

Option C. Increased Peripheral Resistance: Increased peripheral resistance (SVR) is not present in all types of shock. For example, septic and anaphylactic shock are characterized by decreased SVR due to widespread vasodilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased tissue perfusion is a universal characteristic of all types of shock, leading to inadequate oxygen and nutrient delivery to tissues.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ligament of Treitz

 

The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It is a part of the duodenojejunal junction.

 

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower Gl bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ampulla of Vater: The ampulla of Vater is the point where the pancreatic duct and common bile duct converge and enter the second part of the duodenum. It is an essential structure for the drainage of both bile and pancreatic enzymes into the duodenum. It is not used as a demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Option C. Superior duodenal flexure: The superior duodenal flexure is the bend in the duodenum as it transitions from the first part (horizontal) to the second part (descending).

 

Option D. Ileocecal junction: The ileocecal junction is the point where the ileum meets the cecum. The ileocecal valve is present here, preventing the reflux of colonic contents into the ileum. While it's an important anatomical landmark in the gastrointestinal tract, it's not used as the demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ligament of Treitz is the anatomical demarcation point used to differentiate upper gastrointestinal bleeding (proximal to the ligament) from lower gastrointestinal bleeding (distal to the ligament).

questions.text: Phenomenon of renal colic, swelling in the loin which disappears after passing urine is called? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dietl's crisis

 

Explanation:

 

Dietl's crisis refers to a clinical triad of renal colic (severe flank pain), intermittent loin swelling, and relief of symptoms with passage of a large volume of urine. This occurs in cases of intermittent hydronephrosis, particularly with pelvi-ureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction. 

 

The swelling represents the distended renal pelvis that becomes temporarily obstructed, causing pain, and then relieves when the obstruction clears, allowing passage of the accumulated urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Murphy's triad - This refers to right lower quadrant pain, vomiting, and fever, which are characteristic of acute appendicitis.

 

Option B. Saint's triad - This is the association of diverticular disease, gallstones, and hiatal hernia, completely unrelated to urinary symptoms.

 

Option D. Charcot's triad - This includes right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and fever, associated with ascending cholangitis due to biliary obstruction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dietl's crisis represents intermittent hydronephrosis with the characteristic triad of loin pain, swelling, and relief after passing large volumes of urine, typically seen in patients with PUJ obstruction.

questions.text: A female presented with pain and redness of the left breast. She is lactating for the last 3 months. On examination, local temperature is raised and cracked nipple is noted. Ultrasound of breast was suggestive of significant liquid collection. What should be the next line of management? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incision and drainage

 

The clinical presentation of a postpartum female with fever, pain, and swelling of the breast, along with an ultrasound showing fluid collection, is indicative of a breast abscess.

 

Breast abscesses are more common in lactating women due to faulty breastfeeding techniques, with cracked nipples being a significant risk factor. The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus, often sourced from the oropharynx of the child.

 

This is the definitive treatment for a breast abscess, especially when there is a significant collection of fluid, as indicated by the ultrasound.

 

Diagnosis:


Diagnosis is based on clinical examination and confirmed by ultrasound, which shows fluid collection indicative of an abscess.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Primary Treatment: Incision and drainage (I&D) is the mainstay of treatment for a confirmed breast abscess.
  • Antibiotics: While antibiotics (such as Amoxiclav) are important, they are adjunctive to the drainage procedure.
  • Needle Aspirations: Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration can be attempted, especially if the abscess is small. However, if multiple attempts fail, incision and drainage become necessary.
  • Suction Catheter Drainage: For large abscesses (>3 cm or >30 cc), suction catheter drainage is an effective management strategy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone are not sufficient to treat a breast abscess as they do not address the pus collection. They are used in conjunction with drainage procedures.

 

Option B. Multiple needle aspirations: Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration can be attempted, but if it fails after at least two attempts, incision and drainage are indicated.

 

Option D. Breast support: While providing breast support is important for comfort and to help reduce pain, it is not a primary treatment method for a breast abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for a breast abscess in a lactating woman is incision and drainage, along with the use of antibiotics to manage infection.

questions.text: A woman in her early 40s comes to your clinic, displaying a winding, pronounced swelling that covers the left region of her scalp and face, as visible in the provided image. Upon physical examination, you notice the swelling exhibits a rhythmic pulsation. When listening to the area with a stethoscope, a sound indicative of turbulent blood flow - a bruit - is heard. What could be the most probable diagnosis in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cirsoid Aneurysm

 

The above image is suggestive of a Cirsoid aneurysm.

 

  1. Definition: Cirsoid aneurysms, also known as arteriovenous fistulas or arteriovenous malformations, are abnormal connections between arteries and veins without the usual intervening capillaries.
  2. Common locations: They most commonly occur in the scalp and face, although they can occur in other locations in the body.
  3. Causes: They can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired, often as a result of trauma.
  4. Symptoms: Cirsoid aneurysms often present as a pulsatile mass, sometimes accompanied by a bruit (a sound heard over an artery due to turbulent blood flow). They can cause cosmetic concerns, headaches, and in severe cases, bleeding.
  5. Diagnosis: They can be diagnosed through physical examination and imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT, or MRI. Angiography can provide a detailed view of the blood vessels.
  6. Treatment: Treatment options include surgical excision, embolization (blocking off the abnormal vessels), or a combination of both. The choice of treatment depends on the size and location of the aneurysm, and the patient's overall health status.
  7. Complications: If left untreated, they can result in complications such as bleeding, ulceration, and, rarely, heart failure due to the increased blood flow through the malformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis:

 

  • Location: Neurofibromatosis (NF) is a genetic disorder that can affect multiple systems, including the skin and nerves.
  • Symptoms: Symptoms vary but can include skin tumors (neurofibromas), café-au-lait spots, and neurological problems

 

 

Option B. Liposarcoma:

 

  • Location: Liposarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that typically arises in fat cells in various parts of the body, including the limbs and abdomen.
  • Causes: The exact cause is often unknown, but some genetic factors may contribute. Symptoms: Symptoms may include a painless lump, swelling, or pain in the affected area.

 

Option D. Varicocele:

 

  • Location: Varicoceles are dilated veins in the scrotum, specifically in the spermatic cord. Causes: Varicoceles often develop due to faulty valves in the testicular veins, which allow blood to pool in the scrotum.
  • Symptoms: They may cause a dull ache or discomfort in the scrotum, especially after prolonged standing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cirsoid aneurysms are arteriovenous malformations commonly found in the scalp and face, presenting as pulsatile masses with associated bruits. Proper diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications such as bleeding and cosmetic concerns.

choices.text: Reassure, continue to follow-up the patient

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady came to the surgery OPD with 2 cm single, mobile, asymptomatic breast lump with well-defined margins, noticed by the patient herself on self-breast examination, presented to the OPD. She was diagnosed as having a benign breast lesion. As the treating doctor, what would you recommend to this patient? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reassure, continue to follow-up patient

 

The case scenario is suggestive of a fibroadenoma, which is a common benign breast tumor often seen in younger women. Fibroadenomas are typically smooth, round, and rubbery lumps that are mobile and asymptomatic. They are well-defined on clinical examination and imaging studies like mammography, where they can show characteristic features such as popcorn calcifications (BIRADS 2). Most fibroadenomas do not require surgical intervention unless they are symptomatic, growing, or causing significant anxiety to the patient.

 

For small, asymptomatic fibroadenomas that are confirmed to be benign, a conservative approach with reassurance and regular follow-ups is usually recommended. This approach involves monitoring the lump periodically to detect any changes in size or characteristics early. Most fibroadenomas resolve spontaneously over time.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Surgical Excision:
    • Surgical excision (wide local excision) is considered for fibroadenomas that are large, symptomatic, rapidly growing, or causing significant anxiety to the patient. It is also done for lumps with suspicious features to rule out malignancy definitively.
  • Option C. Biopsy:
    • A biopsy (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology - FNAC or Core Needle Biopsy) is performed to diagnose the nature of a breast lump. In this case, since the lesion has already been diagnosed as benign and has typical features of a fibroadenoma, a biopsy is not immediately necessary unless there are atypical features or changes in the lump.
  • Option D. Give Danazol:
    • Danazol is used to treat fibrocystic breast disease to reduce the size and tenderness of breast lumps. However, fibroadenomas are not typically treated with danazol, as this medication is not effective for this type of benign tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For small, asymptomatic fibroadenomas confirmed to be benign, the recommended management is reassurance and regular follow-up to monitor for any changes in the lump.

choices.text: Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis
Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with diffuse abdominal pain and abdominal wall rigidity. Exploratory laparotomy was done and the following was found. What would you do in the management of this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Simple primary repair

 

The scenario described suggests that the patient has a perforation of the small bowel, as indicated by the image showing a hole in the intestine. Abdominal wall rigidity is indicative of peritonitis, which results from the leakage of intestinal contents into the peritoneal cavity due to a perforation. The provided images and description align with a small bowel perforation, likely in the jejunum or ileum.

 

In cases of small bowel perforations, particularly when the perforation is small, the standard management is a simple primary repair. This involves suturing the perforation directly, which is often sufficient to manage the defect without the need for more extensive surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis:
This is typically reserved for cases where the perforation is large, there are multiple perforations, or when the perforation is associated with a pathological condition like a stricture like in tubercular perforation. In the case described, a simple primary repair is usually sufficient.

 

Option B. Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch: This procedure, known as an omental patch or Graham's patch, is more commonly used for duodenal ulcers, not for small bowel perforations.

 

Option D. Purse string suture: This technique is not commonly used for repairing small bowel perforations. It is more suitable for specific types of perforations or fistulas but not typically indicated in the described scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For small bowel perforations, particularly in the jejunum or ileum, the primary approach is often a simple primary repair. This involves directly suturing the perforation and is usually effective for managing small perforations.

questions.text: Which of the following provides the most accurate information for reporting the 'T stage' of esophageal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Endoscopic USG

 

Explanation:

 

Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the most accurate modality for determining the T stage (depth of tumor invasion) in esophageal carcinoma. EUS provides highly detailed images of the layers of the esophageal wall, allowing precise determination of tumor depth invasion through visualization of the mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and adventitia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT - INCORRECT CT scan is useful for identifying haematogenous metastases and is primarily used to identify distant metastasis (M stage). CT has limited axial resolution which precludes reliable assessment of both depth of wall penetration and early lymph node involvement.

 

Option B. PET - INCORRECT PET scanning is valuable for detecting distant metastatic disease not seen on CT alone, focused on identifying metabolically active tumor sites, but lacks the resolution to accurately determine depth of tumor penetration through the esophageal wall layers.

 

Option C. MRI - INCORRECT MRI doesn't expose the patient to ionizing radiation but is primarily used for metastasis detection rather than precise T-staging. It lacks the resolution needed for accurate T-staging compared to EUS.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For precise T-staging of esophageal carcinoma, endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is superior as it visualizes the multi-layered structure of the esophageal wall, allowing accurate determination of tumor depth penetration.

questions.text: You are working as an ER physician, and a patient with a laceration has just been brought in. You decide to use the interrupted suturing technique to close the wound. As you prepare to suture, you recall that the angle of needle placement is crucial for optimal wound closure. What is the correct angle of needle placement for interrupted suturing technique? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 90 degrees

 

This is the correct angle because inserting the needle perpendicular to the skin (at a 90-degree angle) ensures optimal tissue eversion and approximation of the wound edges. It allows for consistent depth and distance from the wound edge on both the entry and exit points of the needle, which is crucial for the interrupted suturing technique to effectively close the wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To properly execute interrupted sutures, it is recommended that the needle is inserted and exited the skin at a right angle (90 degrees). It is important to rotate the needle through the tissue to prevent unnecessary enlargement of the needle hole. The distance between the entry point of the suture and the edge of the wound should be nearly equal to the depth of tissue that is being sutured. Additionally, it is advised to leave a distance that is twice this measurement between two consecutive sutures.

questions.text: M3 incisional hernia refers to: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Umbilical

 

According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 incisional hernia refers to umbilical hernia.

 

M=Midline, L=Lateral

 

M1: defect up to 3 cm below xiphoid

 

M3: Defect within 3 cm of umbilicus (above or below)

 

M5: Defect up to 3 cm above pubis

 

M2: Defects between M1 and M3

 

M4: Defects between M3 and M5.

questions.text: A team of emergency responders has been called to the scene of a bomb blast in a crowded city center. Upon arrival, they find multiple casualties with various injuries, including blast injuries. In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Liver

 

Explanation:

 

In the context of blast injuries, the liver is considered the least vulnerable to the direct effects of the blast wave due to its solid and dense nature. The primary blast wave from an explosion affects air-filled and delicate structures more significantly than dense, solid organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GI tract: The GI tract, especially the hollow parts, is susceptible to blast injuries due to the presence of air. Typical injuries include subserosal hemorrhage and perforation of the intestines.

 

Option B. Lungs: The lungs are highly vulnerable to blast injuries because they are air-filled and delicate. Blast waves can cause severe pulmonary barotrauma, leading to conditions such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pulmonary contusion.

 

Option D. Ear drum: The eardrum is extremely sensitive to the pressure changes caused by a blast wave. It is a thin membrane that can easily rupture in an explosion, making it one of the most commonly injured organs in such scenarios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a blast injury, the liver is the least vulnerable organ to the primary blast wave compared to the GI tract, lungs, and eardrum, which are more susceptible due to their air-filled nature and delicate structures.

choices.text: Lipase is more specific than amylase
Lipase requires 30 days to return to baseline
Lipase reflects the severity of pancreatitis
More than 75% of cases have hypercalcemia on admission

questions.text: Which of these is seen in acute pancreatitis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lipase is more specific than amylase

 

Lipase is indeed more specific than amylase in diagnosing acute pancreatitis. Amylase can be elevated in multiple other acute GI emergencies, while lipase elevation is more specific to pancreatic pathology. Lipase typically returns to baseline within 1-2 weeks (usually 12-15 days), not 30 days as stated in option B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipase requires 30 days to return to baseline: Incorrect. Lipase returns to baseline in 1-2 weeks, not 30 days

 

Option C. Lipase reflects the severity of pancreatitis: Incorrect. Neither lipase nor amylase levels reflect disease severity. Severity is assessed using other parameters like:

 

  • Atlanta classification
  • BISAP score
  • Older scoring systems like Ranson's criteria
  • CT severity index

 

Option D. More than 75% of cases have hypercalcemia on admission: Incorrect. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically develop hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, due to saponification of calcium with free fatty acids. Hypercalcemia is very unusual in acute pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Lipase is more pancreas-specific than amylase and is the preferred diagnostic marker for acute pancreatitis.
  • Lipase does NOT indicate severity.
  • Most patients have hypocalcemia, NOT hypercalcemia.
  • Severity is assessed using clinical scores (BISAP, Ranson’s, APACHE-II) and imaging.

 

1st Investigation:

 

  1. Pancreatic enzymes are elevated in blood
    • Serum amylase (non specific) → rises early (4-6 hours of attack)
    • Serum lipase → rises 12-24 hours later (sensitive and specific, test of choice)
  2. Imaging → no need for diagnosis, only when unsure of dx, rule out etiology like gall stone Imaging modality of choice → CECT abdomen (done after 72 hours of symptoms)

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain, whose elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40 and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and the ultrasound image provided suggest the diagnosis of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).
  • ADPKD is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys. Over time, these cysts can enlarge and decrease the functioning of the kidneys, leading to kidney failure.
  • Besides renal symptoms, patients with ADPKD can have other complications, such as cerebral aneurysms (which can rupture leading to strokes), liver cysts, and cardiac valvular diseases.
  • The combination of multiple episodes of hematuria, hypertension, familial history, and the ultrasound findings make this diagnosis the most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults. It originates from the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It may present with hematuria, pain in the flank or loin area, and a palpable abdominal mass. However, the familial context, with the brother's early death from a stroke, doesn't typically fit with the presentation of RCC. RCC occurs in an elderly age group.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis of the kidney: Tuberculosis (TB) can affect the kidneys, usually as a secondary site from pulmonary TB. This can lead to a chronic inflammatory response. Kidney TB might present with sterile pyuria (white blood cells in urine without bacterial growth), hematuria, and even systemic symptoms of TB like fever, weight loss, and night sweats. The clinical scenario provided doesn't specifically lean toward this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD): ARPKD is another inherited form of polycystic kidney disease. However, it's different from ADPKD in that it presents much earlier, usually in childhood or infancy. Symptoms in ARPKD are typically severe and can include kidney failure and liver problems at a young age.

 

  • Given the combination of clinical symptoms, family history, and ultrasound findings, the most probable diagnosis in this scenario is option B, Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure, hypertension, and a higher risk of cerebral aneurysms, making it crucial to consider family history and typical ultrasound findings in the diagnosis.

questions.text:
What diseases' risk is elevated due to smoking? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Duct ectasia
  2. Fibroadenoma
  3. Mondor's disease
  4. Breast carcinoma
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Cigarette smoking elevates the likelihood of experiencing duct ectasia, Mondor's disease, and breast carcinoma.

 

1. Duct ectasia: Typically seen in smokers. Patient presents with greenish Nipple discharge and Lump in breast with nipple retraction. Management is done by Conical excision of ductal system - Hadfield procedure.

 

3. Mondor's disease: Superficial thrombophlebitis of veins of breast / chest wall or axilla – males. Patient presents with cord like, thick, tender initially. Most common vein involves lateral thoracic vein. Smoking was identified as a possible contributing element in the development of Mondor's disease.

 

4. Breast carcinoma: Risk factors involve Age > 60, Early menarche (< 12 years), late menopause (>55 years), nulli-parity, late age of first child birth, Hormone replacement therapy, Inadequate breast feeding (breast feeding for > 12 months reduces risk), Alcohol & smoking consumption, obesity, Prior chest wall radiation, Family history.

 

Other Option:

 

2. Fibroadenoma: Tumor of breast arising from ductal epithelium or fibrous elements or both. It has two components – fibrous or stromal elements + glandular elements. Patient presents with slow growing lump (2-3cm), mobile like a mouse in breast. Smoking is not a risk factor for fibroadenomas.

choices.text: Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

questions.text: An adult male patient in his 60s presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of haematuria. Upon examination, a 2x2 cm bladder mass was observed, which was diagnosed as a low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. What is the recommended course of action for this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

 

For this patient diagnosed with bladder carcinoma, transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) is the most beneficial treatment option among the given choices. Based on the available evidence, there is no indication of muscle invasion or advanced cancer, suggesting that the most probable pathological stage is pTa - low grade non-muscle invasive cancer, for which TURBT followed by intravesical chemotherapy is the recommended treatment. TURBT is performed to pathologically stage the tumor and determine the appropriate course of treatment. Intravesical therapy using chemotherapy or immunotherapy is administered after TURBT to eradicate any residual cancer cells in the bladder lining, but it is not effective against cancers that have spread to muscle layers.

 

This is the correct answer. TURBT is a standard initial procedure for diagnosing and treating visible tumors, especially for low-grade, noninvasive disease. It involves removing the tumor from the bladder wall via the urethra. The stage of the bladder cancer can be determined by examining the sample removed during a TURBT, which aids in further treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Resection with ileal conduit: This is a more invasive surgery typically used for muscle invasive bladder cancers (radical cystectomy). An ileal conduit is a urinary diversion technique where urine is redirected through a piece of the intestine and out to a stoma on the abdomen.

 

Option C. Partial cystectomy with bladder reconstruction: This involves removing a part of the bladder affected by cancer. It's reserved for select patients where the tumor is localized and not near the urethral or ureteral openings. It might not be the first line of treatment for a 2x2 cm low-grade tumor.

 

Option D. Neo-adjuvant chemotherapy: This refers to chemotherapy given before a primary treatment in advanced cancers. In the case of bladder cancer, neo-adjuvant chemotherapy might be used before a surgery to shrink the tumor size or improve outcomes. However, for a low-grade, small tumor, it is not typically the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-muscle invasive bladder tumors (pTa/pT1): TUR-BT + Intravesical chemotherapy

 

Muscle invasive (pT2/pT3 and some pT4): Radical cystectomy + Ileal conduit

questions.text: In a solid organ transplantation, which organ is associated with a higher incidence of rejection? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lungs

 

Lung transplantation is associated with a higher incidence of rejection compared to other solid organ transplants due to the lungs' constant exposure to environmental antigens and their role in gas exchange, which increases the risk of immune-mediated injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intestine: Intestinal transplantation also carries a high risk of rejection, but it is less common than lung rejection and is often associated with complications such as graft-versus-host disease.

 

Option C. Kidney: Kidney transplantation has a relatively lower incidence of rejection compared to lung and intestinal transplants due to the kidney's immunologically privileged status and the availability of effective immunosuppressive medications.

 

Option D. Heart: While heart transplantation can also lead to rejection, it generally has a lower incidence compared to lung transplantation, possibly due to differences in the immune response and the heart's unique anatomical and physiological characteristics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lung transplantation is associated with a higher incidence of rejection compared to other solid organ transplants due to the lungs' constant exposure to environmental antigens, emphasizing the need for vigilant monitoring and immunosuppressive therapy in lung transplant recipients.

questions.text: A young female presents with pain in lower abdomen and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling, lateral and below the public tubercle. X-ray show intestinal obstruction. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strangulated femoral hernia

 

This type of hernia occurs just below the inguinal ligament, where the abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal. It is more common in women, especially those with repeated pregnancies. The description of the swelling's location lateral and below the pubic tubercle fits well with a femoral hernia. If the hernia becomes strangulated, it means that the blood supply to the herniated tissue is compromised, leading to severe pain, vomiting, and signs of intestinal obstruction as seen on X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adhesions: Bands of fibrous tissue that can form between abdominal tissues and organs, often as a result of surgery can lead to intestinal obstruction if they cause the intestines to twist or kink. However, adhesions themselves do not cause noticeable swelling as described in the scenario.

 

Option B. Strangulated inguinal hernia: This will present with a swelling above the pubic tubercle.

 

Option D. Appendicular mass: This refers to a mass formed from a swollen, inflamed appendix often associated with appendicitis. While this can lead to pain and vomiting, the location of the pain and swelling typically would be around the lower right quadrant of the abdomen, not below the pubic tubercle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Given the location of the swelling and the associated symptoms, the most probable diagnosis is a Strangulated Femoral Hernia. This condition requires prompt surgical intervention to relieve the obstruction and restore blood flow to the entrapped tissues to prevent further complications such as tissue necrosis.

questions.text: What is the cut-off score for defining Severe Acute Pancreatitis from below? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. APACHE II Score > 8

 

Explanation:

 

Several prognostic scoring systems are used to predict severity in acute pancreatitis. The threshold for severe pancreatitis using the APACHE II scoring system is >8. This score helps clinicians identify patients at higher risk of complications who may require intensive monitoring and aggressive management. Severity stratification is particularly important to determine which patients might develop persistent organ failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ranson Score >1 - INCORRECT The Ranson score threshold for severe acute pancreatitis is ≥3 (not >1). This score is assessed at admission and 48 hours later, with criteria including age, white blood cell count, blood glucose, LDH, and AST initially, followed by hematocrit fall, BUN rise, calcium levels, and other parameters at 48 hours.

 

Option B. Imrie Score > 6 - INCORRECT The Imrie score (Glasgow score) defines severe pancreatitis as ≥3 criteria present, not >6. The Glasgow criteria include 8 parameters total, similar to the Ranson criteria but assessed at different timepoints.

 

Option D. ROME Score > 3 - INCORRECT The ROME Score is not a validated or recognized scoring system for acute pancreatitis severity assessment. The primary scoring systems used in clinical practice include Ranson, Glasgow, APACHE II, BISAP, and modified Marshall scoring systems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute pancreatitis is defined by persistent organ failure (>48 hours) and can be predicted using several scoring systems, with APACHE II score >8 being an important threshold for identifying high-risk patients.

questions.text: What is the site for needle insertion in emergency thoracocentesis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper border of lower rib

 

In emergency thoracocentesis, the needle is inserted along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid injury to the intercostal vessels and nerve, which are located along the lower border of the upper rib.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lower border of lower rib: This option is incorrect because it still risks injuring intercostal vessels and nerves.

 

Option C. Lower border of upper rib: This option is incorrect because the intercostal vessels and nerve are located here, increasing the risk of injury.

 

Option D. Middle of intercostal space: This option is incorrect because it does not provide a clear anatomical landmark, increasing the risk of accidental injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For thoracocentesis, always insert the needle along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid damaging the intercostal vessels and nerves located at the lower border of the upper rib.
